Lateral aspect.gif) ::: ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Ch64 Fibularis longus, brevis, tertius muscle @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 - Neuman @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 ::: ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Fibularis brevis Middle lateral surface of Fibula Base of 5th MT Superficial Fibular n.
L5 - S1		 TCJ: PF
STJ: Eversion
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Middle lateral surface of fibula @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} 5th metatarsal base @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} [Superficial Fibular N.]({{< var ref-superficial-fibular-nerve.path >}}) ([L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}}), [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - **TCJ**: PF @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - **STJ**: Eversion @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Tendon "The origin for the fibularis (peroneus) brevis is more distal to the fibularis (peroneus) longus and lies deeper. It becomes superficial on the lateral aspect of the foot, at its insertion on the tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal." @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 # Length Testing # Strength Testing The fibularis longus, Fibularis brevis, and Fibularis Tertius cannot be differentiated from eachother, so the same MMT is used for all 3: - Patient is in supine and the other, with the foot over the edge of the table and the ankle in the anatomic position. Resistance is applied to the lateral border of the forefoot
